articles.headline: Interior Official Assails Agency for Ethics Slide
articles.snippet: The agency’s inspector general accused officials of widespread ethical failures from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.
articles.abstract: The agency’s inspector general accused officials of widespread ethical failures from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.

articles.headline: Wolfowitz Corruption Drive Rattles World Bank
articles.snippet: World Bank president Paul D. Wolfowitz’s fight against corruption in poor countries has drawn criticism for its aggressive approach.
articles.abstract: World Bank president Paul D. Wolfowitz’s fight against corruption in poor countries has drawn criticism for its aggressive approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 — In his first 15 months as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, waging an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to nations including India, Chad, Kenya, Congo, Ethiopia and Bangladesh.

articles.headline: New Product by Nintendo for Holidays
articles.snippet: Nintendo plans to release its new Wii video game console in the Americas in November.
articles.abstract: Nintendo plans to release its new Wii video game console in the Americas in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that may allow Nintendo of Japan to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, the company plans to announce today that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States.

articles.headline: What, Ghosn Worry?
articles.snippet: Nissan-Renault’s chief Carlos Ghosn, anointed by some as the auto industry’s savior, suddenly seems to be on the defensive.
articles.abstract: Nissan-Renault’s chief Carlos Ghosn, anointed by some as the auto industry’s savior, suddenly seems to be on the defensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULOGNE-BILLANCOURT, France, Sept. 12 — For an executive who runs two giant carmakers, in France and Japan, and is trying to extend his influence over a third — General Motors in America — this dreary suburb of Paris is as close as Carlos Ghosn gets to home turf.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: New at Apple: Smaller iPods, Bigger Ideas
articles.snippet: Apple’s latest developments are laying the groundwork for some ambitious ideas down the road.
articles.abstract: Apple’s latest developments are laying the groundwork for some ambitious ideas down the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod.

articles.headline: Philanthropy Google’s Way: Not the Usual
articles.snippet: Unlike most charities, Google’s new philanthropy will be for-profit, a move that could greatly increase its range and flexibility.
articles.abstract: Unlike most charities, Google’s new philanthropy will be for-profit, a move that could greatly increase its range and flexibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 — The ambitious founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming.

articles.headline: Tiny Firm’s H.P. Link Scrutinized
articles.snippet: California prosecutors are focusing on how a small private investigation firm in Boston ended up handling work for one of the largest technology companies in the world.
articles.abstract: California prosecutors are focusing on how a small private investigation firm in Boston ended up handling work for one of the largest technology companies in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13  California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing in part on a small private investigation firm in suburban Boston, operating out of a yellow house with black shutters in a quiet neighborhood.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Damon Darlin

articles.headline: Cut Off, Gazan Economy Nears Collapse
articles.snippet: With the Palestinian Authority cut off from funds after the election of Hamas, the Gaza Strip is enduring a severe economic depression with growing signs of malnutrition.
articles.abstract: With the Palestinian Authority cut off from funds after the election of Hamas, the Gaza Strip is enduring a severe economic depression with growing signs of malnutrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip, Sept. 12 — For the last week, Zidan Abu Reziq has been sleeping outside, next to his plantings on a small square of sand he expropriated.

articles.headline: New Product by Nintendo for Holidays
articles.snippet: In a move that may allow Nintendo of Japan to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, the company plans to announce today that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday ...
articles.abstract: In a move that may allow Nintendo of Japan to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, the company plans to announce today that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States.     Nintendo executives said this week that the company would also announce today that more than 25 new games would be available for its video game machine this year, a substantial portfolio from several genres that is intended to help the company broaden the appeal of its console. The company plans to ship four million of the Wii consoles worldwide this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that may allow Nintendo of Japan to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, the company plans to announce today that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States.

articles.headline: Philanthropy Google’s Way: Not the Usual
articles.snippet: The ambitious founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming.      But unlike most charities, this one will be...
articles.abstract: The ambitious founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming.      But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit, allowing it to fund start-up companies, form partnerships with venture capitalists and even lobby Congress. It will also pay taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 - The ambitious founders of Google, the popular search engine company, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming.

articles.headline: Interior Official Assails Agency for Ethics Slide
articles.snippet: The Interior Department's chief official responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations accused the top officials at the agency on Wednesday of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.    ...
articles.abstract: The Interior Department's chief official responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations accused the top officials at the agency on Wednesday of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.     ''Simply stated, short of a crime, anything goes at the highest levels of the Department of the Interior,'' charged Earl E. Devaney, the Interior Department's inspector general, at a hearing of the House Government Reform subcommittee on energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - The Interior Department's chief official responsible for investigating abuses and overseeing operations accused the top officials at the agency on Wednesday of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence.

articles.headline: New at Apple: Smaller iPods, Bigger Ideas
articles.snippet: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod.     But this summer, the company was ...
articles.abstract: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod.     But this summer, the company was unusually quiet. Apple watchers online concluded that something really, really big must be in the works. A wide-screen iPod! An iPhone! A hovercar!
articles.lead_paragraph: APPLE, these days, is an innovation factory. The company releases so many products, so often, you get the idea that everyone there just runs around yelling ideas. If this is Thursday, there must be a new iPod.

articles.headline: What, Ghosn Worry?
articles.snippet: For an executive who runs two giant carmakers, in France and Japan, and is trying to extend his influence over a third -- General Motors in America -- this dreary suburb of Paris is as close as Carlos Ghosn gets to home turf.     And yet here at t...
articles.abstract: For an executive who runs two giant carmakers, in France and Japan, and is trying to extend his influence over a third -- General Motors in America -- this dreary suburb of Paris is as close as Carlos Ghosn gets to home turf.     And yet here at the headquarters of Renault, Mr. Ghosn, the man who is arguably the world's most celebrated auto executive, anointed by some as the industry's savior, seemed oddly on the defensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULOGNE-BILLANCOURT, France, Sept. 12 - For an executive who runs two giant carmakers, in France and Japan, and is trying to extend his influence over a third -- General Motors in America -- this dreary suburb of Paris is as close as Carlos Ghosn gets to home turf.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Tiny Firm’s H.P. Link Scrutinized
articles.snippet: California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing in part on a small private investigation firm in suburban Boston, operating out of a yellow house with black shutters in a quiet neighborhood.     How such a tiny fir...
articles.abstract: California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing in part on a small private investigation firm in suburban Boston, operating out of a yellow house with black shutters in a quiet neighborhood.     How such a tiny firm ended up handling work for H.P., one of the largest technology companies in the world, as it tried to find out who had leaked company secrets is not clear. But other private investigators said on Wednesday that the situation was not surprising, because corporations in need of such services often end up relying on a chain of subcontractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 - California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing in part on a small private investigation firm in suburban Boston, operating out of a yellow house with black shutters in a quiet neighborhood.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Damon Darlin

articles.headline: Cut Off, Gazan Economy Nears Collapse
articles.snippet: For the last week, Zidan Abu Reziq has been sleeping outside, next to his plantings on a small square of sand he expropriated.     The Abu Reziqs, like many of the large, destitute refugee families in this shrapneled, tumbledown slum, need to plan...
articles.abstract: For the last week, Zidan Abu Reziq has been sleeping outside, next to his plantings on a small square of sand he expropriated.     The Abu Reziqs, like many of the large, destitute refugee families in this shrapneled, tumbledown slum, need to plant to eat. They took the land and planted it with vegetables, an investment of about $50, most of the money that the United Nations Relief and Works Agency gave them to buy school uniforms for the children.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip, Sept. 12 - For the last week, Zidan Abu Reziq has been sleeping outside, next to his plantings on a small square of sand he expropriated.

articles.headline: Wolfowitz Corruption Drive Rattles World Bank
articles.snippet: In his first 15 months as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, waging an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in l...
articles.abstract: In his first 15 months as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, waging an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to nations including India, Chad, Kenya, Congo, Ethiopia and Bangladesh.     It is a new incarnation for Mr. Wolfowitz, a neoconservative intellectual who was a primary architect of the Iraq war during four years as deputy secretary of defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - In his first 15 months as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, waging an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to nations including India, Chad, Kenya, Congo, Ethiopia and Bangladesh.

articles.headline: Panel in Senate Backs Bush Plan for Eavesdropping
articles.snippet: The White House took a critical step on Wednesday in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror ...
articles.abstract: The White House took a critical step on Wednesday in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects being held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.      The mixed results signaled the tough road the White House faces in trying to sell the two key planks in its national security agenda to sometimes skeptical Congressional Republicans less than two months before the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - The White House took a critical step on Wednesday in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects being held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Kate Zernike
